Patch Set 12:

This feature is simple and conceptually easy to understand and implement. It simply changes the behavior when in failsafe mode, so that the final output PWM will not exceed the configured failsafe PWM value, even when the PID loop computed PWM is greater.

Invoking the "stepwise" controller would be overkill and add a large amount of additional complication. As I understand it, the stepwise controller adds the additional processing step of quantizing the output PWM into a smaller number of notches, for motor controllers that only have a few discrete speed settings and don't have the ability to accept the PWM as an arbitrary percentage.

I recommend just adding the feature flag, as originally proposed, instead of trying to do this with "stepwise".

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> This feature is simple and conceptually easy to understand and implement.

But in terms of overall phosphor-pid-control features, it makes things more complex.  Do you really want to maintain both, including testing interactions between them?

> It simply changes the behavior when in failsafe mode, so that the final output PWM will not exceed the configured failsafe PWM value, even when the PID loop computed PWM is greater.
> 
> Invoking the "stepwise" controller would be overkill and add a large amount of additional complication. As I understand it, the stepwise controller adds the additional processing step of quantizing the output PWM into a smaller number of notches, for motor controllers that only have a few discrete speed settings and don't have the ability to accept the PWM as an arbitrary percentage.

Despite being called stepwise, they're linearly interpolated, so, if you're using the same 1:1 scale, no new "notches" are added.

> 
> I recommend just adding the feature flag, as originally proposed, instead of trying to do this with "stepwise".

Up to you, you're the maintainer now.  Please make sure that Brandon and/or you test and define the behavior when both a stepwise ceiling record and a cap_failsafe_pwm flag are present, that is going to be important to be able to document when someone does it.

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> > Patch Set 12:
> > 
> > This feature is simple and conceptually easy to understand and implement.
> 
> But in terms of overall phosphor-pid-control features, it makes things more complex.  Do you really want to maintain both, including testing interactions between them?
> 
> > It simply changes the behavior when in failsafe mode, so that the final output PWM will not exceed the configured failsafe PWM value, even when the PID loop computed PWM is greater.
> > 
> > Invoking the "stepwise" controller would be overkill and add a large amount of additional complication. As I understand it, the stepwise controller adds the additional processing step of quantizing the output PWM into a smaller number of notches, for motor controllers that only have a few discrete speed settings and don't have the ability to accept the PWM as an arbitrary percentage.
> 
> Despite being called stepwise, they're linearly interpolated, so, if you're using the same 1:1 scale, no new "notches" are added.
> 
> > 
> > I recommend just adding the feature flag, as originally proposed, instead of trying to do this with "stepwise".
> 
> Up to you, you're the maintainer now.  Please make sure that Brandon and/or you test and define the behavior when both a stepwise ceiling record and a cap_failsafe_pwm flag are present, that is going to be important to be able to document when someone does it.

As for testing, I think that tests should be added to both cases (the option disabled, and the option enabled), to make sure it does the right thing. Fortunately, the program is already testing-friendly, so adding these tests hopefully should not be too disruptive.

As for stepwise, I still think it adds an additional layer of complexity that doesn't need to be there, since our controller is 1:1 and doesn't need the stepwise mapping layer.

Patch Set 13:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> > Patch Set 12:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 12:
> > > 
> > > This feature is simple and conceptually easy to understand and implement.
> > 
> > But in terms of overall phosphor-pid-control features, it makes things more complex.  Do you really want to maintain both, including testing interactions between them?
> > 
> > > It simply changes the behavior when in failsafe mode, so that the final output PWM will not exceed the configured failsafe PWM value, even when the PID loop computed PWM is greater.
> > > 
> > > Invoking the "stepwise" controller would be overkill and add a large amount of additional complication. As I understand it, the stepwise controller adds the additional processing step of quantizing the output PWM into a smaller number of notches, for motor controllers that only have a few discrete speed settings and don't have the ability to accept the PWM as an arbitrary percentage.
> > 
> > Despite being called stepwise, they're linearly interpolated, so, if you're using the same 1:1 scale, no new "notches" are added.
> > 
> > > 
> > > I recommend just adding the feature flag, as originally proposed, instead of trying to do this with "stepwise".
> > 
> > Up to you, you're the maintainer now.  Please make sure that Brandon and/or you test and define the behavior when both a stepwise ceiling record and a cap_failsafe_pwm flag are present, that is going to be important to be able to document when someone does it.
> 
> As for testing, I think that tests should be added to both cases (the option disabled, and the option enabled), to make sure it does the right thing. Fortunately, the program is already testing-friendly, so adding these tests hopefully should not be too disruptive.
> 
> As for stepwise, I still think it adds an additional layer of complexity that doesn't need to be there, since our controller is 1:1 and doesn't need the stepwise mapping layer.

Entirely up to you;  So long as the behavior is defined (and hopefully documented) if you think adding this new feature plays nicely with stepwise, that's fine with me.

If "doesn't need the stepwise mapping layer" means, we should just ignore it, that probably won't fly for the systems that currently use it, but again, up to you.

Patch Set 17:

(1 comment)

This seems awfully similar to the Stepwise curve of type Ceiling.  To get this case, you'd have no inputs, and a single point specified at the failsafe speed, but it would get you the same result (I think).

Might be worth looking at if we're implementing the same feature twice.

This is to be able to use this feature which is WIP https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/38112

We'd like to lower the failsafePercent dynamically when the host is down (where sensors from the host report NaN and margin sensors are stuck at what they reported last) - this causes the PID loop to get into failsafe mode but the calculated RPM to go up to 100%.
This sounds like exactly what stepwise records were built to do?  They can clamp fan speeds based on some arbitrary input (or no input in this case).

I'm not familiar enough with the stepwise records, is this referring to the TODO section of the configure.md? https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/blob/master/configure.md#type--stepwise

We would like to control the PID as a normal PID and only go into this "Ceiling" type in failsafe or when we instruct it to, is this possible with the stepwise records?

> I'm not familiar enough with the stepwise records, is this referring to the TODO section of the configure.md? https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/blob/master/configure.md#type--stepwise

Here's an example of one:
https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/ec98491a00c5dcffae6be362e483380c807f234c/configurations/R2000%20Chassis.json#L480

Essentially they can set and upper and lower clamp on your fan speeds, optionally dependent on another sensor (usually ambient air temps).

> 
> We would like to control the PID as a normal PID and only go into this "Ceiling" type in failsafe or when we instruct it to, is this possible with the stepwise records?

It should be, if it isn't already today.  I'd have to look at the code to see exactly the order that the clamps are applied in.
Reviving this discussion - this is to be used for platforms without entity-manager (it's using static sensor stack), so I'm not sure if we can use EM changes for this feature

This is no longer necessary, right? There is now a compile-time flag to set the failsafe behavior: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/commit/bcdeb83ca05ed0fa352290ec8f78bb28a2d1d2fb
Yes, that's correct. Let me abandon this review
